arch:property.oc:show_val: This locus is a surface beneath the surface L168, abutting the wall L157. On its south side is the ashy soil that is L167. Prior to excavation the surface appeared rocky with many flat-lying potsherds and other artifacts. The last surface, L168, was separated from it by not more than 8-10cm. We determined it was a surface once excavation had already begun, having thought it was fill until we were already in it. There were multiple stones and flat-lying potsherds exposed at the top of it. These materials were mainly concentrated next to wall L157 and extended out from the wall about 3ft. It was poorly preserved everywhere else, and at places failed to produce much of this same material. We took it all together as one locus because there was no clear change anywhere besides the absence of surfacey material and we assumed that at least in some places it was nothing more than poor preservation that caused this. This locus produced a lot of pottery, bone, and lithic, as well as some carbon and a ceramic figure that is broken off at the end. At site we could not tell what ths figure was. It produced this type of material for about 8cm. At this level the soil changed and artifact inclusions lessened. Probablythe fill between this and L168 was taken out accidently with L168. Also, this locus seems very much to be apart of a series of outside surfaces pressed very tightly together. Moreover, it"s level proved to be very irregular and part of its surface was still visible as apart of the fill layer below it, L170.

arch:note.arch:string: Contexts excavated in trenches were recorded using the "locus system." A locus is any discrete three-dimensional entity excavated in a trench. The key to the locus system is the recognition that a locus is any one thing. Differences in soil composition or texture are therefore as important as, for example, the difference between a pit and a wall. If two entities were distinct, they were considered separate loci and were therefore assigned separate locus numbers. It should also be noted that every context excavated in a trench was given a locus number and thus the trench itself is made up completely of excavated loci.

arch:property.oc:show_val: Rocks, pebbles, pottery, bone, other artifacts
Tightly packing materials together through use and other floors forming on top of it.
Appears to be one in a series of many tightly-packed floor surfaces.

oc:metadata.dc:title: Kenan Tepe: Area E / Trench 2 / Locus 169 (Locus)
